Hypermedia Hype?

Hypermedia Hype? Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): Hypermedia

(3) Why Hypermedia?

  • Avoiding coupling by API capabilities
    • RPC and URI styles require clients to know about capabilities
    • Hypermedia allows clients to discover them ar runtime
  • Enabling clients to be driven by resource state
    • Links are only available when an interaction is possible
    • Links can be ignored if uninteresting or unknown to the client
  • Allowing APIs to evolve by interlinking new resources
    • Clients ignore links they are not interested in
    • Clients can use new workflows if they are interested


Hypermedia Hype? Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): Hypermedia

(4) Hypermedia Claims

  • Giving clients choice by providing them with dynamic controls
    • Presence of control information is controlled by server
    • Usage of control information is controlled by client
  • Allowing API evolution by dynamically extending content and controls
    • Unknown/uninteresting links are always ignored by clients
    • Versioning is reduced to clients experiencing richer resources
  • Seamless model covering APIs and API landscapes
    • Controls guide clients on their journey to complete workflows
    • Client application goals are not necessarily structured by API


Hypermedia Hype? Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): Hypermedia

(5) How to do Hypermedia

  • Hypermedia needs core foundations to work seamlessly at scale
    • Resources represent anything that clients may be interested in
    • Identification must make sure that all resources are addressed uniformly
    • Interaction should be uniform to make resource access universal
    • Representations have to combine content and controls to guide clients
    • Hyperlinks should be typed to allow clients to choose


Hypermedia Design

Hypermedia Design Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): Hypermedia

(7) Hypermedia = Content + Controls

  • Hypermedia combines data representing content and control
    • Content is used to represent the current resource
    • Controls are a special additional aspect of resource representation
    • Affordances is another term used for hypermedia controls
  • Hypermedia embeds content into a web of interlinked resources
    • Outgoing links are represented in the resource (or the protocol)
    • Incoming links are not represented in the target resource
  • Webby hypermedia is a set of imperfectly interlinked resources
    • Outgoing links can break when the target disappears
    • Incoming links are hard to figure out and to keep up to date
    • Clients driven by hypermedia always gracefully handle problems


Hypermedia Design Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): Hypermedia

(8) Hypermedia Representations

  • Hypermedia representations must represent content and controls
    • Some representations can only handle resource-to-resource links
    • In some cases links from and/or to fragments are also required
  • Resource fragments can anchor links within resources
    • Target fragments can be identified by using URI fragment syntax
    • Source fragments can be established by embedding outgoing links in content
  • Hypermedia representations are often designed from the ground up
    • Popular metamodels (JSON or XML) are often used as foundation
    • Generic hypermedia formats have seen relatively little success so far


Hypermedia Design Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): Hypermedia

(9) Web Linking

  • RFC 5988 Web Linking [https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988] defines two aspects of Web links
    • The HTTP Link header field [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Link] for HTTP-level links
    • A standardized way to type links and a registry for well-known link relation types [http://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml]
  • Link [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/http-header/Link] can be used to represent resource-level links
    • Including links in HTTP or in the representation is equivalent
    • Hypermedia can be used without embedding links in representations
    • Supports linking for representations that have no ability/possibility for linking


Hypermedia Design Erik Wilde (dret@ca.com): Hypermedia

(10) Link Relations

  • Link relations [http://webconcepts.info/concepts/link-relation/] allow simple and consistent typing of links
    • Hypermedia clients choose links based on their application goals
    • Link relations are a simple shared vocabulary at the Web level
  • Link relations can be either registered or extension values
    • Registered values are strings and specified and registered by IANA [http://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml]
    • Extension values are URIs and have no Web-level meaning
    • APIs must document supported link relations and their semantics in context
